awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Ensuring Sustainable Energy Storage Operations in the US Electricity Grid
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project investigates the environmental effects of energy storage operations in the United States using life-cycle assessments and electricity system engineering-economic modeling. The first objective of the proposed work is to understand the climate, health and environmental effects of operating energy storage devices on the electricity grid. The second objective is to propose new electricity system policies that allow the economic benefits of storage to be captured without causing inadvertent system emissions. Energy storage deployments are expected to increase rapidly in the coming years, but the environmental consequences of their operation phase are generally unknown. The effort will build on the researchers' prior work on the topic and will estimate the emissions effects of several different energy storage technologies providing energy arbitrage, renewable energy integration, and frequency regulation services.  In addition, project activities include the participation of both graduate and undergraduate research assistants, through an undergraduate summer research program. The public is being engaged on the research topic through development of a freely-distributed "Emissions and Renewables" expansion to the popular board game, Power Grid.

This research project is utilizing electricity system modeling approaches, marginal emissions factors, and emissions-related damage estimation tools.  The analysis also includes an evaluation of a variety of likely policy interventions that can improve the environmental footprint of energy storage, including performance standards and alternative operational strategies. As part of this work, existing concepts are being coupled in new ways, combining energy storage operational models with marginal emissions factors to estimate climate, health and environmental impacts. Part of this effort involves developing new forecasts of marginal emissions factors for use in both this research project and by others examining the expected effects of future changes to the electricity grid. Finally, policy or market limitations on new energy storage, which have not been considered up to now, are an integral part of the research effort.  Energy storage will be rapidly adopted in the coming decades. Policies that ensure sustainable development of these technologies are needed before large-scale deployment occurs, and the results of this work could be used directly in the formation of new policy.

por.por_cntn:
Stationary storage is an increasingly important technology in the United States electricity grid. This is especially true for regions where a large portion of the electricity generation comes from variable energy sources, such as wind and solar. In those cases, fast ramping generation or storage is needed to maintain the power grid stability. Storage can be used to provide different services to the grid, such as energy, capacity, and frequency regulation. One key aspect regarding the environmental sustainability of storage is that as the storage technology charges (or discharges) it will be using (or displacing) the existing energy electricity from the grid. The emissions intensity of air pollutants and greenhouse gases associated with electricity generation varies by geography and over time. Thus, charging a storage device at one specific hour (or region) versus other another may have quite different emissions implications. 

Some of the key air pollutant emissions of concern come from fossil fuel power plants (especially coal plants) that emit fine particulate matter (PM2.5), as well as SO2 and NOx. These two last pollutants may react in the atmosphere and form secondary particulate matter. Particulate matter is a pollutant that is associated with premature mortality. Other emissions of concern are greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide and methane, which contribute to climate change.   

To understand the effects of these emissions, interdisciplinary research that combines the understanding of technical and economic storage operations with the modeling of air pollutant emissions induced or displaced by other electricity generators because of storage, as well as the modeling of air pollutant emissions to their respective effects in the form of premature mortality and climate change. 

Thus, in this project, we studied the climate, health, and environmental effects of operating energy storage devices on the electricity grid for different services. 

Intellectual Merit: As part of this work, existing concepts were be coupled in novel ways, combining energy storage operational and economic models with emissions factors to estimate climate, health, and environmental impacts. During this project, we have found that: 

  • Under current conditions, when storage acts as a price taker, storage tends to increase coal generation and decrease natural gas generation in the West and Midwest – resulting in a net increase in emissions. Storage has the opposite effect in New England and California. 
  • When using instead a different model that allows storage to shift the dispatch patterns in the New York Independent System Operator (NYISO), the Midcontinent ISO (MISO), and California ISO (CAISO), we find that the operating income of all other generating units is reduced unless retirement of unprofitable plants is included.
  • We also examined the consequences of considering longer time horizons by accounting for the retirement of power plants that lose sufficient annual revenue from new storage. Under that scenario we find that the least flexible generation—coal, nuclear, and solar—gain the most operating income with storage. In all cases, simple cycle gas turbines lose the most operating income as they are offset by storage during the discharge phase and then retired in the long term. 

As part of this project, we also developed new dispatch models that accounted for a rapidly changing electricity generation fleet, and with that we were able to develop marginal emissions and damage factors that are based on the marginal generator being dispatch and compared such results with the results of the formerly developed method of estimating marginal emissions and damage factors, which relied on historical emissions and regressions.

Broader Impacts: The results developed in this project can be used by policy makers and regulators to mitigate the negative externalities associated with the operations of stationary energy storage in the U.S. grids. During the project, we have delivered presentations to electricity system operators and energy storage industry groups, advising them on how to manage or reduce these effects. The project also involved students and post-doctoral fellow which are now equipped to tackle these sorts of interdisciplinary and sustainability related research questions.
